snippet.textDisplay:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves. Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious. Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation. The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this. The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing. Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.
snippet.textOriginal:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves.  Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious.  Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation.  The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this.  The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing.  Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.

snippet.textDisplay: It was nice explanation of exponential growth model . However it is not model of corona virus fortunately. I believe so,because since outbreak of the corona virus in China in December 2019 there were ca 82 000 of people infected until March 11( in over 3 months) ,which is 0.0057 % of whole China population. Today' China submitted announcement that number of new infections decreased.In the world growth of infection is also related to the way it is handled in different countries (one can compare rapid or exponential growth in Italy with rather slower rate of growth in Germany and France ) which means there are many other factors that can affect the algorithm of corona virus spreading around the world. I am not an expert I'm just guessing.

snippet.textDisplay:
While I greatly admire your other videos, I think this one is trivializing the subject. Predicting pandemic dynamics is not even remotely close to being as easy as fitting a logistic curve and calculating derivatives. One must account for so many variables and sometimes unmeasurable factors like mutations of viral genome which might give a rise for a new strain with different virulency and incubation period. Also, ignoring the eventuality of one person being infected and recovering multiple times during a wider period can't just be arbitrarily ruled out, as the model then could as well be thrown out of the window at spot.


I know that you are just presenting a simplified model just to make it easier for us to grasp the concepts of exponential growth, but based on the comments of most viewers I think they got a wrong impression that coronavirus pandemic will be a simple and completely predictable subject once we discover few figures describing it.
snippet.textOriginal:
While I greatly admire your other videos, I think this one is trivializing the subject. Predicting pandemic dynamics is not even remotely close to being as easy as fitting a logistic curve and calculating derivatives. One must account for so many variables and sometimes unmeasurable factors like mutations of viral genome which might give a rise for a new strain with different virulency and incubation period. Also, ignoring the eventuality of one person being infected and recovering multiple times during a wider period can't just be arbitrarily ruled out, as the model then could as well be thrown out of the window at spot.


I know that you are just presenting a simplified model just to make it easier for us to grasp the concepts of exponential growth, but based on the comments of most viewers I think they got a wrong impression that coronavirus pandemic will be a simple and completely predictable subject once we discover few figures describing it.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hello, your video has been a lot useful for me to understand the current situation (not only in terms of numbers) so thank you very much!!! I'm Italian i live in a town that counts zero infected for now, there is a bit of ignorance around but authorities are working pretty well. My family is at home except for my dad that is out for work and he has to carry around a permission in order to not get fined. Because I'm a noob at functions I have a question for you, the question is: How the raising/decreasing of the constants E and p can affect the position of the inflection point? i mean, is the inflection point related to the constants or it appears when the graph approaches the total population number regardless of the constants?
This may be a stupid question but to be clear I made this very questionable representation of the two options

( https://ibb.co/1zmQxg5 ).
Thank you for your time, hope you doing well !!!

snippet.textDisplay: There is an error in this model. This assumes that all those being infected stay infected. That is not true. Assuming the virus runs its course in about 21 days - from the time of infection to the time of being declared infection-free or death, each day, a population approximately the size of N(d-21) will move out of the total. So the summation is only for a moving window of 21 days. Taking this into consideration, can you please redo the video? would love to see the distribution.
snippet.textOriginal: There is an error in this model. This assumes that all those being infected stay infected. That is not true. Assuming the virus runs its course in about 21 days - from the time of infection to the time of being declared infection-free or death, each day, a population approximately the size of N(d-21) will move out of the total. So the summation is only for a moving window of 21 days. Taking this into consideration, can you please redo the video? would love to see the distribution.

snippet.textDisplay: The growth factor stated at 58s is 1.15 to 1.25 (with the upper bound actually being 1.29). If we stick to 1.15 then after 61 days we have 105 million cases, as shown at the end of the video. If we lower it to 1.05, we have 412,000. If we slip to 1.25 (which is the upper bound of the average mentioned here) there are 17 billion cases. If we slip to 1.29 (a growth rate we have already seen) then there are 117 billion cases after 61 days.  These numbers are silly. So let's see how long it takes to reach 7billion. At 1.25 it will take 57 days, at 1.29 it will take 55 days. So let's hope for the best. 1.05. In that case, it will take 9 months to reach 7 billion cases. Tell people you love them.
snippet.textOriginal: The growth factor stated at 58s is 1.15 to 1.25 (with the upper bound actually being 1.29). If we stick to 1.15 then after 61 days we have 105 million cases, as shown at the end of the video. If we lower it to 1.05, we have 412,000. If we slip to 1.25 (which is the upper bound of the average mentioned here) there are 17 billion cases. If we slip to 1.29 (a growth rate we have already seen) then there are 117 billion cases after 61 days.  These numbers are silly. So let's see how long it takes to reach 7billion. At 1.25 it will take 57 days, at 1.29 it will take 55 days. So let's hope for the best. 1.05. In that case, it will take 9 months to reach 7 billion cases. Tell people you love them.

snippet.textDisplay: At some point in February the WHO - and other country's health agencies - started using the term Cases.  Prior to that they were reporting on the number of confirmed illnesses and presumptive coronavirus infections.  A case is the sum of these two numbers.  Not sure many people know this.  I prefer seeing the number of confirmed illnesses.  Maybe it's still exponential, but the numbers are definitely lower.
snippet.textOriginal: At some point in February the WHO - and other country's health agencies - started using the term Cases.  Prior to that they were reporting on the number of confirmed illnesses and presumptive coronavirus infections.  A case is the sum of these two numbers.  Not sure many people know this.  I prefer seeing the number of confirmed illnesses.  Maybe it's still exponential, but the numbers are definitely lower.

snippet.textDisplay: ...Epidemics follow the Bell Curve - Farr’s Laws of Epidemics - William Farr (1807–1883),. He observed that epidemics appear to go through a regular course, and decline. In his Second Annual Report (1840), he demonstrated mathematically that the decline in mortality of a waning epidemic occurs at a uniformly accelerating rate. He constructed mathematical models to explain the natural history of epidemic diseases, often correctly and elegantly. He also observed that epidemics appear to be generated in unhealthy places, and go through a regular course, and decline https://books.google.com/books?id=E-OZbEmPSTkC&pg=PA133#v=onepage&q=farr&f=false
snippet.textOriginal: ...Epidemics follow the Bell Curve - Farr’s Laws of Epidemics - William Farr (1807–1883),. He observed that epidemics appear to go through a regular course, and decline. In his Second Annual Report (1840), he demonstrated mathematically that the decline in mortality of a waning epidemic occurs at a uniformly accelerating rate. He constructed mathematical models to explain the natural history of epidemic diseases, often correctly and elegantly.  He also observed that epidemics appear to be generated in unhealthy places, and go through a regular course, and decline  https://books.google.com/books?id=E-OZbEmPSTkC&pg=PA133#v=onepage&q=farr&f=false

snippet.textDisplay:
Coronaviruses belong to the family Coronaviridae. Alpha- and beta-coronaviruses usually infect
mammals, while gamma and delta coronaviruses usually infect birds and fish. Canine coronavirus,
which can cause mild diarrhea and feline coronavirus, which can cause feline infectious peritonitis
(FIP), are both alpha-coronaviruses. These coronaviruses are not associated with the current
coronavirus outbreak. Until the appearance of SARS-Cov-2, which belongs to the beta-coronaviruses,
there were only six known coronaviruses capable of infecting humans and causing respiratory disease,
including the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus SARS-CoV (identified in 2002/2003) and
Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus MERS-CoV (identified in 2012). SARS-Cov-2 is
genetically more related to SARS-CoV than MERS-CoV, but both are beta-coronaviruses with their
origins in bats. While it is not known whether COVID-19 will behave the same way as SARS and MERS, so at this point your dogs are safe.
snippet.textOriginal:
Coronaviruses belong to the family Coronaviridae. Alpha- and beta-coronaviruses usually infect 
mammals, while gamma and delta coronaviruses usually infect birds and fish. Canine coronavirus, 
which can cause mild diarrhea and feline coronavirus, which can cause feline infectious peritonitis 
(FIP), are both alpha-coronaviruses. These coronaviruses are not associated with the current 
coronavirus outbreak. Until the appearance of SARS-Cov-2, which belongs to the beta-coronaviruses, 
there were only six known coronaviruses capable of infecting humans and causing respiratory disease, 
including the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus SARS-CoV (identified in 2002/2003) and 
Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus MERS-CoV (identified in 2012). SARS-Cov-2 is 
genetically more related to SARS-CoV than MERS-CoV, but both are beta-coronaviruses with their 
origins in bats. While it is not known whether COVID-19 will behave the same way as SARS and MERS, so at this point your dogs are safe.

I cant understand the growth factor.
if N(d+1) = Gf*Nd,
why Gf is not not simply ~ Nd/N(d-1)?

China is definitely way beyond the inflection point. Which is remarkable given the size of the population and its density. Currently there are "only" 15,998 active cases, whilst the total is 80,790. So it's slowing down in China. So it's definitely containable given enough time.

snippet.textDisplay: Anyone else trying to apply daily case numbers to come up with an infection rate and to look for a possible inflection point?  The data is a little jumpy so I'm using moving averages for US cases since 2/29/20.  My average growth rate is around 1.29 so far for US cases of CoV since 2/29.  At that rate we will overtake total China cases before the end of the month.

snippet.textDisplay: 7:03 Does this mean that an inflection point of a local population (achieved by quarantine) does not represent the inflection point of the entire population? snippet.textOriginal: 7:03 Does this mean that an inflection point of a local population (achieved by quarantine) does not represent the inflection point of the entire population?
